title: Oxidation States of Stoichiometric Ni Doped CeO2 Aerogel
content: The water-gas shift (WGS) reaction converting H2O and CO into CO2 and H2 typically uses Fe-Cr oxides as catalytic hosts, but these can leak water-soluble Cr6+ so alternative transition metals are being sought [1-3]. Nickel is an earth-abundant metal that has shown promise as a replacement for Cr-based systems. We find that stoichiometric Ni doping of CeO2 aerogel beneficially impacts catalytic conversion of CO into H2 with suppressed methanol production up to 5 %at Ni in the WGS reaction. However, the exact catalytic pathways caused by atomically-dispersed Ni are not known but can be attributed to both the highly-porous, covalently-bonded CeO2 aerogel structure and its prevention of aggregation and oxidation of elemental Ni into the less-catalytically-desirable NiOx species. Using Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy (STEM-EELS) on Ni-doped CeO2, or Ni­xCe­1-xO2, aerogels, we identify ∼ 1nm Ni-rich regions within a homogenously-dispersed Ni-containing background and probe related oxidation states of the Ni-rich site-specific regions by comparison to undoped CeO2 aerogel.
